It grips its tail, which spews electricity, and\nthen beats down opponents with the power of\nits electrified fist.
A single Electivire can provide enough electricity\nfor all the buildings in a big city for a year.
They dwell in volcanic craters. According to\nwhat is known, a single pair of male and female\nMagmortar lives in one volcano.
From its arm, it launches fireballs hotter than\n3,500 degrees Fahrenheit. Its arm starts to\nmelt when it fires a whole barrage.
There are still quite a few factories that rely on\nthe flames provided by Magmortar to\nprocess metals.
Magmortar takes down its enemies by shooting\nfireballs, which burn them to a blackened crisp.\nIt avoids this method when hunting prey.
Its cellular composition is closer to that of a\nplant than an animal. It uses photosynthesis to\nproduce its energy supply without eating food.
The younger they are, the more they smell like\nfresh grass. With age, their fragrance takes on\nthe odor of fallen leaves.
Although it doesn’t like disputes, it will sharpen\nthe leaf on its tail into a blade and fight if it has\nto protect its friends.
It gets its nutrition from photosynthesis. It lives\na quiet life deep in forests where clean\nrivers flow.
It can control its body temperature at will.\nThis enables it to freeze the moisture in the\natmosphere, creating flurries of diamond dust.
It freezes its fur into icicles, spiky and sharp,\nand tackles its prey.
It protects itself by freezing its fur into sharp\nneedles. It can drop its body temperature below\n–75 degrees Fahrenheit.
It can instantaneously freeze any moisture\nthat’s around it, creating ice pellets to shoot at\nits prey.
In order to create a more advanced Pokémon, an\nadditional program was installed, but apparently\nit contained a defect that makes it move oddly.
Its program was modified to facilitate\nextra-dimensional activities, but that led to\nnoticeably strange behavior.
Its behavior is noticeably unstable, which is\napparently due to the incompetence of the\nengineer who updated its programming.
A faulty update was added to its programming.\nIts behavior is noticeably strange, so the\nexperiment may have been a failure.
It radiates such a powerful magnetic field that\nnearby electrical appliances become unusable.
The main body controls three mobile units called\nMini-Noses, which it maneuvers to catch prey.
Although it can control its units known as\nMini-Noses, they sometimes get lost and don’t\ncome back.
It uses three small units to catch prey and\nbattle enemies. The main body mostly just\ngives orders.
When it finds humans or Pokémon it likes,\nit freezes them and takes them to its chilly den,\nwhere they become decorations.
The soul of a woman lost on a snowy mountain\npossessed an icicle, becoming this Pokémon.\nThe food it most relishes is the souls of men.
It freezes hikers who have come to climb snowy\nmountains and carries them back to its home. It\nonly goes after men it thinks are handsome.
It’s said that on nights of terrible blizzards, it\ncomes down to human settlements. If you hear\nit knocking at your door, do not open it!
Because it doesn’t yelp, it’s extremely popular\nwith Trainers who live in apartment buildings.
The long fur surrounding its face functions as\nradar, enabling it to probe the condition of its\nbattle opponents.
This Pokémon has excellent judgment.\nIf it decides it can’t defeat an opponent,\nit immediately turns tail and vamooses.
This Pokémon is popular with beginners\nbecause it’s intelligent, obedient to its Trainer’s\ncommands, and easy to raise.
Its dense black fur grows continuously. The high\ncost of keeping its hard fur properly groomed\nmakes this a troublesome Pokémon to train.
This Pokémon obeys its master’s orders\nfaithfully. However, it refuses to listen to\nanything said by a person it doesn’t respect.
The longer its black fur grows, the harder and\nmore impervious it gets. Claws and fangs can’t\neasily penetrate it.
It has been living with people for so long that\nportrayals of it can be found on the walls of\ncaves from long, long ago.
Intelligent, good-natured, and valiant,\nit’s a trustworthy partner on rescue teams.
With this wise Pokémon, there could be no\nconcern that it would ever attack people. Some\nparents even trust it to babysit.
It pays no mind to the cold, thanks to its long\nwarm coat. Stoutland in Alola look a\nlittle uncomfortable.
Its fur is long and thick. A long time ago in cold\nregions, every household kept a Stoutland.
Born deep within the ground, it compares itself\nwith similar species, such as Geodude and\nCarbink, to settle which has the hardest body.
The hexagonal cavity is its ear. It walks in the\ndirection of sounds it hears, but if the sounds\ncease, it panics and topples over.
The hexagonal hole is its ear. Deep in that ear is\nan energy core, so if you stick your hand in\nthere, Roggenrola will be very angry!
It was found in a fissure in a layer of exposed\nrock. The material that makes up its body is\ndirt from several hundred years ago.
Its orange crystal is a mass of energy.\nJust one crystal fragment would provide\nenough fuel for a hundred dump trucks.
It explores caves in search of underground\nwater. It’s not comfortable around water, so\nthis Pokémon takes great care in lapping it up.
The energy overflowing from its body has\nturned into orange crystals that are hard\nenough to smash diamonds.
Its orange crystals are lumps of powerful\nenergy. They’re valuable, so Boldore is\nsometimes targeted for them.
The blasts of energy it makes from sunbeams\nhave terrifying power. However, it’s not able to\nfire its blasts at night or on rainy days.
Known for its hefty horsepower, this Pokémon\nis a popular partner for construction workers.
When it fires off energy with all its might, the\npower creates countless fissures on its body.
It absorbs rays of sunlight and shoots out\nenergy. It’s usually lurking deep beneath\nthe surface.
When it finds others of its kind, they all stick\ntogether. When enough of them have collected,\nthe mass resembles a cumulonimbus cloud.
Pillows and beds stuffed with cotton exhaled\nby Cottonee are soft and puffy, light and airy—\naltogether top quality.
To protect itself, it shoots cotton from its body.\nWhen it gets wet in the rain, its cotton grows\nmoist and heavy, and it can’t move as well.
When attacked, it expels cotton from its\nbody to create a diversion. The cotton it loses\ngrows back in quickly.
It rides on the wind and slips into people’s\nhomes. After it has turned a room into a cotton-\nfilled mess, it giggles to itself and takes off.
This Pokémon appears, riding upon the wind.\nBut if the wind gusts up, it’ll blow the cotton on\nthis Pokémon’s head clean off.
This nuisance sneaks into people’s homes,\nwhere it hides important things and scatters\ncotton all over the place.
Whimsicott doesn’t live in a fixed location. It\nfloats around on whirling winds, appearing all\nover the place to perform its mischief.
Although the leaves on its head are bitter\nenough to cause dizziness, they provide relief\nfrom weariness—even more so when boiled.
By pruning the leaves on its head with\nregularity, this Pokémon can be grown into a\nfine plump shape.
Some say if you dry the leaves on its head, boil\nthem down, and drink the infusion, your vigor\nwill return, so Petilil is popular with the elderly.
They prefer clean water and soil. When the\nenvironment they live in turns bad, the whole\nbunch will up and move to a new area.
No matter how much time and money is spent\nraising it, its flowers are the most beautiful\nwhen they bloom in the wild.
As soon as it finds a male to be its partner,\nthe beautiful flower on its head darkens,\ndroops, and withers away.
The fragrance of its flower differs slightly\ndepending on the soil where it grew up.\nSniffing the aroma calms your heart and mind.
It’s well liked by other Pokémon because of its\nbeauty. The flower on its head needs constant\ncare, or it will soon wither and rot.
Savage, violent Pokémon, red and blue Basculin\nare always fighting each other over territory.
When a school of Basculin appears in a lake,\neverything else disappears, except for Corphish\nand Crawdaunt. That’s how violent Basculin are.
It submerges itself in sand and moves as if\nswimming. This wise behavior keeps its enemies\nfrom finding it and maintains its temperature.
It conceals itself in the sand and chomps down\non the legs of any prey that unwarily walk over\nit. Its favorite food is Trapinch.
Alola, where it’s warm all year round, is a\ncomfortable environment for this Pokémon.\nSometimes you’ll even see it outside of deserts.
Sandile’s still not good at hunting, so it mostly\neats things that have collapsed in the desert.\nIt’s called “the cleaner of the desert.”
They move in groups of a few individuals.\nA female is often the leader of the group, and\nthe males will gather food.
Thanks to the special membrane covering its\neyes, it can see its surroundings clearly, even in\nthe middle of the night.
Krokorok really hates it when its body gets\ncold. On nights when the temperature drops,\nit digs deep into the desert sands.
It buries some of its prey in the sand to use as\nemergency meals when its hunts\nare unsuccessful.
Its unique faculty of sight can detect small prey\nmore than 30 miles away, even in the midst of\na sandstorm.
After clamping down with its powerful jaws,\nit twists its body around to rip its prey in half.
When it spots prey, even at a distance of over\n30 miles, it swims through the desert as if it\nwere water, then jumps out and chomps them.
It conceals itself in sandstorms that Flygon\nwhip up and waits patiently for prey to appear.
They move in small groups, walking around lazily.\nAnyone who makes eye contact gets smacked\nwith a headbutt.
It stretches its saggy skin up to its neck to\nprotect itself. The saggier their skin, the more\nrespect they garner.
This Pokémon may be rude, but it takes very\ngood care of its family, its friends, and its turf.
It taunts its opponents by spitting. It has a\ncertain territory that it never leaves its whole\nlife long.
Based on studies of its skeletal structure, it can\napparently dive to ocean depths of over half\na mile.
Reputed to be the ancestor of most turtle\nPokémon, it lived in warm seas approximately\na hundred million years ago.
It was restored from an ancient fossil. Tirtouga\nlived in the sea but came up onto the land to\nsearch for prey.
Its hunting grounds encompassed a broad area,\nfrom the land to more than half a mile deep in\nthe ocean.
It constructed its sturdy shell by crunching and\nswallowing the hard shells or bones of its prey.
Active both on land and in the sea, this\nPokémon drags its land-based prey into the\nwater to finish it off.
Its jaws are terrifyingly powerful. It could eat\nOmastar and Omanyte whole and not be\nbothered in the slightest by their shells.
Carracosta eats every last bit of the prey it\ncatches, even the shells and bones, to further\nstrengthen its sturdy shell.
It is the ancestor of all bird Pokémon. Archen\nitself could not actually fly but moved by\nhopping from treetop to treetop.
To all appearances flightless, it was able to\nglide down from tall treetops to snag its prey.
Once thought to be the ancestor of all bird\nPokémon, some of the latest research suggests\nthat may not be the case.
Restored from a fossil, this ancient bird\nPokémon has wings but can’t yet fly.
Although apparently able to fly, they tended\nto run along the ground, averaging speeds of\nroughly 25 mph.
They hunted in flocks. When one Archeops had\nthe prey cornered, another would swoop on it.
This ancient Pokémon’s plumage is delicate,\nso if anyone other than an experienced\nprofessional tries to restore it, they will fail.
Said to be an ancestor of bird Pokémon, the\nmuscles it uses to flap its wings are still weak,\nso it needs a long runway in order to take off.
Unsanitary places are what they like best.\nThey can be spotted in Alola, often with Grimer\nin hot pursuit.
It gorges on trash until its stomach is full. Then\nit belches toxic gas. An unlucky whiff of gas will\nput a person in the hospital.
Poisonous gas leaks out of it when it breathes.\nMuk that catch a whiff of that stench will\ncome drooling.
If a young Pokémon or child breathes in the\ntoxic gas that Trubbish belches out, it could be\na life-threatening situation.
Beware the poisonous liquid it shoots from its\nright arm. If even a little of it gets on you, you’ll\nexperience the effects of the unidentified toxin.
For a time, their numbers increased explosively\nin Alola. Since the arrival of Grimer, their\npopulation has decreased dramatically.
It locks opponents in place with its left hand,\nimmobilizing them by entirely dousing their\nbodies with poisonous liquid.
Some say the reason Garbodor in Alola are a\nlittle stronger than their counterparts elsewhere\nis the presence of Muk, their natural enemy.
This Pokémon has a cowardly disposition, so\nwhen it’s not around friends, it basically\nalways stays transformed as something else.
If a normally talkative child suddenly stops\ntalking, it may have been replaced by Zorua.
It doesn’t just transform itself—it also has the\npower to make hundreds of people see\nits illusions.
If it thinks humans are going to discover its den,\nZoroark shows them visions that make them\nwander around in the woods.
A clean freak that will not allow even the\nslightest mess, it uses its tail like a mop to\nthoroughly clean any and all filth.
When its tail has gotten dirty from self-cleaning\nor from cleaning its nest, Minccino spends a\nwhole day washing its tail in clean spring water.
The white parts of its coat are covered in an oil\nsecreted from its body, so this Pokémon can\nslide right away from its enemies’ attacks.
The oil that seeps from its body is really\nsmooth. For people troubled by bad skin,\nthis oil is an effective treatment.
Born of an icicle, this Pokémon uses its frosty\nbreath to make ice crystals, causing snow\nto fall.
It feels pleasantly cool when embraced. This\nPokémon is treasured by households in\nwarm regions.
It exhales cold air that is at –58 degrees\nFahrenheit. When it’s in a warm place, it shrinks\nlittle by little.
When the morning sun hit an icicle, it wished not\nto melt, and thus Vanillite was born. At night, it\nburies itself in snow to sleep.
Hot days cause its body to melt. It can be\nrestored by refreezing it, but the process\nleaves its body slightly warped.
This Pokémon has existed since the Ice Age. It\ncontrols particles of ice, freezes its opponents,\nand then shatters them with a headbutt.
It sprays its enemies with grains of ice to freeze\nthem. Most Vanillish in Alola are smaller\nthan average.
This hearty Pokémon survived the Ice Age.\nIt’s incredibly popular in very hot regions.
Each of its two heads has a brain, and when\nthey are in agreement, it attacks its enemies\nby exhaling a violent blizzard.
Even if it loses one of its heads, it can live\nrelatively problem-free. It makes snow clouds\ninside its body.
It blasts blizzards from its two mouths. It can\ncreate snow anywhere, so it gets a lot of love\nfrom skiers and snowboarders.
Vanilluxe is born when two Vanillish, half-melted\nby the day’s light, stick to each other and\nfreeze together in the cold return of night.
It glides using its cape-like membrane.\nElectrical energy scatters from it, shocking\nits friends and foes alike.
It grills berries and bug Pokémon with electric\nshocks and makes a meal of them. It usually\nnests in the holes gouged in trees by Pikipek.
They store up electricity to fly through the air.\nWhen thunder cracks at night, sometimes there\nare almost enough of them to blot out the sky.
As it flies, it scatters electricity around, so bird\nPokémon keep their distance. That’s why\nEmolga can keep all its food to itself.
It wraps its veillike arms and legs around prey\nswimming by and drags them down to the\ndepths of the ocean.
Using the invisible poison spikes on its veillike\narms and legs, it paralyzes its enemies and\ncauses them to drown.
Jellicent is always hanging around fancy cruise\nships and tankers, hoping to drag away its prey.
Fishermen are terrified of Jellicent.\nIt’s rumored to drag them into the sea\nand steal their lives away.
It uses its special mucus to close the wounds of\ninjured Pokémon. The reason for this behavior\nremains unknown.
They float upon the open sea. Many water\nPokémon gather in the area around Alomomola.
Fishermen take them along on long voyages,\nbecause if you have an Alomomola with you,\nthere’ll be no need for a doctor or medicine.
The reason it helps Pokémon in a weakened\ncondition is that any Pokémon coming after\nthem may also attack Alomomola.
It controls tremendous psychic power. Most\nreports of alien sightings are actually just\npeople mistaking Elgyem for an alien.
This Pokémon is shrouded in mystery. It’s said\nto have appeared from a UFO that fell from the\nsky about 50 years ago.
With its psychic powers, it rewrites its\nopponents’ memories. You, too, may have\nalready had your memories rewritten.
It has strong psychic powers. Using its fingers\nthat flash three different colors, it controls its\nopponents and rewrites their memories.
They can often be seen in packs in the morning,\nslowly moving their bodies through a series\nof poses.
They seclude themselves in the mountains and\ndevote themselves to training. The form of their\nkicks and chops differs from pack to pack.
It overwhelms its opponents with continuous\nattacks and then slowly stores up power\nbefore delivering the finishing blow.
When Mienshao lets out a bizarre wail, you’re in\ndanger. A flurry of kicks and chops too fast to\nsee is about to be unleashed!
The red skin on its face is harder than rock.\nIn narrow caves, it squares off against its\nenemies and charges face-first right into them.
It infiltrates tunnels that Pokémon like Diglett\nand Dugtrio have dug and quietly waits for prey\nto pass through.
Its movements are powered by a mysterious\nenergy. It has continued to move since ancient\ntimes, so its power may soon run out.
Although ancient people apparently built it by\nworking with clay, the source of its energy\nis unclear.
Some say that ancient people invented Golurk\nto serve as a laborer. It follows its master’s\norders faithfully.
When the seal on its chest is removed, it rages\nindiscriminately, turning the whole town around\nit into a mountain of rubble.
After shredding its prey, it sharpens its blades\non a stone by the river. Each Pawniard has its\nown favorite sharpening stone.
It follows Bisharp’s orders to a tee when it\nattacks enemies. After slashing an opponent,\nPawniard clangs both of its blades together.
No matter how strong the Bisharp, it’s said\nthat if the blade on its head is chipped, it will\nretire from its position as the boss.
It leads a group of Pawniard. Bisharp doesn’t\neven change its expression when it deals\nthe finishing blow to an opponent.
They pick fights indiscriminately. They grow\nstronger and more powerful each time they\nfaint or are injured.
With its sharp claws, this Pokémon pierces its\nprey, and then it pecks at them. Although it also\nconsumes berries, it’s a carnivore at heart.
With its powerful legs and sturdy claws, it can\ncrack even the hard shells of Shellder and pluck\nout their insides.
Known as a natural-born warrior, soon after its\nhatching, it will challenge its parent to a fight in\norder to gain their acceptance.
With its brave disposition, it fears nothing—not\neven death. Ancient Alolan people respected\nit, referring to it as “the hero of the sky.”
It’s thought that people disturbed their habitats\nin the past, so Braviary banded together to\nfight back.
The more scars it has on its front, the more\nheroic it’s considered to be. Those with many\nscars on their back are mocked by the flock.
Known as “the hero of the skies,” this\nPokémon is so proud and so brave that it will\nnever retreat, even when it’s injured.
It protects its plump posterior with the bones\nof prey it has consumed. As it grows, it \nreplaces the bones.
It can’t fly yet and must wait until its wings have\ndeveloped more. Since it’s still at a playful age,\nit hops around friskily.
Mandibuzz gives it the bones it wears. Vullaby’s\nwings are short, so it can’t fly yet, but it jumps\naround, dreaming of wide open skies.
Its healthy appetite leads to visible growth\nspurts. It often has to replace the bones it\nwears as its size increases.
They adorn themselves beautifully with bones.\nThis is supposedly an effort to attract males,\nbut no male Mandibuzz have ever been found.
It circles in the sky, keeping a keen eye out for\nPokémon in a weakened state. Its choicest food\nis Cubone.
It skillfully arranges the bones of its prey to\nconstruct its nest. Most of the bones\nare Cubone.
It’s always searching for food for Vullaby. When\nit finds a weak Pokémon, Mandibuzz swoops it\nright off to its nest.
When battling opponents, it sprays fire from its\nfive horns. The max temperature of the flames\ncan reach nearly 5,500 degrees Fahrenheit.
It protects itself with flame. Long years ago,\npeople believed Larvesta had a nest on the sun.
As it flies, it scatters its flaming scales. It was\nfeared by ancient people, who referred to it as\n“the rage of the sun.”
According to legends, it was hatched from a\nflaming cocoon to save people and Pokémon\nthat were suffering from the cold.
This amiable Pokémon is easy to train.\nBut when battle is joined, it shows its\nferocious side.
When it’s excited, its temperature can double,\nspiking hormone production in its body.
While it’s an amiable Pokémon, if you touch it\nunexpectedly, it will heat up its body in an\ninstant, and you’ll be burned.
Its body is always warm. Trainers who live in\ncold areas apparently sleep with it in their bed.
From its beak, it fires embers at its prey. Once\nit has caught them, it grills them at high heat\nbefore feasting upon them.
It will not tolerate other Fletchinder entering its\nterritory, which has a radius of several miles.
It scatters embers in the tall grass. Then bug\nPokémon, frightened by the flames, come\nflying out, and Fletchinder gobbles them up.
Its speed right after takeoff already puts it in\nthe top speed class of all bird Pokémon.
Its favorite foods are Wingull and Pikipek.\nIt attacks with a powerful kick and grasps them\nfirmly in its talons.
It zooms directly at its prey at flight speeds of\nclose to 310 mph, while fiery embers scatter\nfrom gaps in its feathers.
Its tough wings don’t allow fire to pass through\nthem. A long time ago, firefighters’ outfits were\nmade from Talonflame wings.
Bird Pokémon make up most of its diet.\nIt approaches at high speeds and smacks them\ndown to the ground with its powerful kick.
When they’re young, they live with a pride. Once\nthey’re able to hunt prey on their own, they’re\nkicked out and have to make their own way.
This hot-blooded Pokémon is filled with\ncuriosity. When it gets angry or starts\nfighting, its short mane gets hot.
The males are usually lazy, but when attacked\nby a strong foe, a male will protect its friends\nwith no regard for its own safety.
The temperature of its breath is over 10,000\ndegrees Fahrenheit, but Pyroar doesn’t use it on\nits prey. This Pokémon prefers to eat raw meat.
It’s not safe without the power of a flower, but\nit will keep traveling around until it finds one\nwith the color and shape it wants.
Flabébé wears a crown made from pollen it’s\ncollected from its flower. The crown has hidden\nhealing properties.
It raises flowers and uses them as weapons.\nThe more gorgeous the blossom, the more\npower it contains.
It gives its own power to flowers, pouring its\nheart into caring for them. Floette never forgives\nanyone who messes up a flower bed.
It controls the flowers it grows. The petal\nblizzards that Florges triggers are overwhelming\nin their beauty and power.
Its life can span several hundred years. It’s said\nto devote its entire life to protecting gardens.
It grows up imitating the behavior of Pangoro,\nwhich it looks up to as a leader.
There’s no point to the leaf in its mouth, aside\nfrom an effort to look cool. It’s mischievous,\nso it’s not well suited to inexperienced Trainers.
It follows Pangoro around like a henchman.\nWhen Pancham makes a big mistake, its leaf\ngets taken away.
It’s desperate to intimidate its opponents.\nBe nice and pretend to be scared if you\ncatch it glaring at you intensely.
It boasts superb physical strength. Those who\nwish to become Pangoro’s Trainer have no\nchoice but to converse with their fists.
From the slight twitches of its bamboo leaf, it\ndeduces its opponent’s movements. It’s eager to\ntussle but kindhearted toward its companions.
This rowdy Pokémon boasts great physical\nstrength. Many Trainers are also smitten by its\nlively character.
Pangoro is the type to talk with its fists. It\ndoesn’t say much as it pummels opponents with\nenough force to send a dump truck flying.
There was an era when aristocrats would\ncompete to see who could trim their Furfrou’s\nfur into the most exquisite style.
Left alone, its fur will grow longer and longer,\nbut it will only allow someone it trusts to cut it.
It draws prey near with its blinking lights and\nthen wraps them up in its long tentacles and\nholds them in place.
When exchanging information with others of its\nkind, it flashes the light-emitting spots on its\nbody in a complex rhythm.
When it comes to strong hypnosis, there’s an\nendless number of people who utilize Malamar\nfor their nefarious deeds.
It flashes the pattern on its torso to control its\nprey and draw them in. The edges of its fins are\nsupremely sharp.
It vanishes into seaweed and remains perfectly\nstill to avoid attacks from large Pokémon.\nRotten seaweed is its main food source.
It’s not good at swimming, so it clings to the\nseaweed. In the Alola region, it’s often found\nnear Dhelmise.
This vicious Pokémon sprays a poisonous liquid\non opponents that come near. For whatever\nreason, it gets along really well with Dhelmise.
It blends in with seaweed to ambush its prey\nand then takes them down with a poisonous\nliquid strong enough to melt metal.
Its claws occasionally fall off, and it keeps a low\nprofile until they grow back. The meat of its\nclaws is so delicious!
It moves around by jetting water from its right\npincer. It has a poor sense of balance, so it’s\nterrible at swimming straight.
It compresses the water it has sucked up and\nthen projects it with enough power to punch a\nhole right through a thick sheet of iron.
Its right arm is packed with meat. When its\npincer falls off, it’s exported to be used as a\ncooking ingredient.
Its large jaw has incredible destructive power.\nSome theories suggest that its restored form is\ndifferent from its form of long ago.
Tyrunt is spoiled and selfish. It may just be\ntrying to frolic, but sometimes the ones it’s\ntrying to frolic with are gravely injured.
Complete restoration is impossible, allowing\nroom for theories that its entire body was\nonce covered in a feather-like coat.
The king of the ancient world, it can easily\ncrunch a car with the devastating strength\nof its enormous jaws.
It lived in cold areas in ancient times. It’s said\nthat when Amaura whinnies, auroras appear in\nthe night sky.
Amaura was restored successfully, but it’s not\nexpected to live long because of the heat of the\ncurrent environment.
An Aurorus was found frozen solid within a\nglacier, just as it appeared long ago, which\nbecame quite a big event in the news.
This usually quiet and kindly Pokémon has a\nsurface temperature of around\n–240 degrees Fahrenheit.
Its ribbonlike feelers give off an aura that\nweakens hostility in its prey, causing them\nto let down their guard. Then it attacks.
When this Pokémon sights its prey, it swirls its\nribbonlike feelers as a distraction. A moment\nlater, it pounces.
Once a fight breaks out, it will unflinchingly\ncharge at dragon Pokémon that are many times\nlarger than itself.
Sylveon wraps its ribbonlike feelers around its\nTrainer’s arm because this touch enables it to\nread its Trainer’s feelings.
It overwhelms opponents with quick moves, but\nsometimes it showboats for too long when it’s\nusing a special move and gets itself into a pinch.
In combat, Hawlucha leaps nimbly about, taking\nadvantage of its opponents’ blind spots. It’s\nalso skilled at using superb submission holds.
It sneaks into people’s homes and steals\nelectricity from their outlets. When your electric\nbill seems off, it’s the handiwork of this rascal.
Its upper whiskers are sensors that survey its\nsurroundings. Its lower whiskers are organs\nthat shoot electricity.
Born from the high temperatures and pressures\ndeep underground, it defends itself by firing\nbeams from the jewel part of its body.
Although this Pokémon is not especially rare,\nits glittering, jewel-draped body draws\nattention from people.
Some say that deep beneath the surface of the\nworld, a pack of Carbink live with their queen in\na kingdom of jewels.
To keep the jewels on their bodies free of\ntarnish, packs of Carbink use their soft manes\nto polish one another’s jewels.
The weakest of all Dragon-type Pokémon,\nit’s unable to breathe if its skin dries out,\nso it sticks to shady places.
Its source of protection is its slimy, germ-laden\nmucous membrane. Anyone who touches it\nneeds some thorough hand-washing.
It uses its horns to check out its surroundings.\nThey’re very sensitive, so if you grab them, it\nwill feel a strong shock and be unable to move.
Its body is mostly water. If it dries out, it will\ndie, so it’s always sitting with perfect stillness\nin the shade.
It has trouble drawing a line between friends\nand food. It will calmly try to melt and eat even\nthose it gets along well with.
This Pokémon’s mucous can dissolve anything.\nToothless, it sprays mucous on its prey. Once\nthey’re nicely dissolved, it slurps them up.
It crawls along sluggishly. The swirly protrusion\non its back is filled with its brain and\nother organs.
Its entire body is covered with gooey mucus\nthat can dissolve anything. Be sure to put\ngloves on if you’re going to touch it.
An amazingly friendly Pokémon, but if left to\nitself, loneliness overcomes it, and it oozes\ngooey tears.
It gets picked on because it’s meek. But then,\nwhoever teased it gets to feel the full force of\nits horns and a good swatting from its thick tail.
It’s very friendly toward people. If you grow\nclose to it, Goodra will hug you with its sticky,\nslime-covered body. Don’t get mad.
Underneath its slimy skin is a thick layer of fat,\nand the combination of the two makes enemies’\nattacks slide right off.
This even-tempered Pokémon has a habit of\ncollecting keys. It will sneak into people’s homes\nto steal their keys.
It inserts its horn into chinks in metal, absorbing\nmetal ions. For some reason, it collects keys.
Although it’s unclear why it collects keys, giving\nit a key makes Klefki very happy. However, it\napparently only likes master keys.
Long ago it lived in mines, but once the minerals\nthat make up its diet became scarcer, Klefki\nbegan appearing in human settlements.
These Pokémon are stumps possessed by the\nspirits of children who died in the forest.\nTheir cries sound like eerie screams.
According to legend, medicine to cure any illness\ncan be made by plucking the green leaves on its\nhead, brewing them, and boiling down the liquid.
By imitating the voice of a child, it causes\npeople to get hopelessly lost deep in the forest.\nIt’s trying to make friends with them.
An unknown spirit came to lodge in a tree\nstump, creating this Pokémon. A cure-all can be\nmade from an infusion of its green leaves.
This Pokémon is said to devour anyone daring to\nravage the forest. To the creatures dwelling in\nthe forest, it offers great kindness.
Through its roots, it exerts control over other\ntrees. A deadly curse falls upon anyone cutting\ndown trees in forests where Trevenant dwell.
It’s feared as a ghost of the forest.\nLumberjacks bring along Fire types, which\nTrevenant hates, when they enter the forest.
This Pokémon controls trees via roots\nstretching from its feet, and it will attack\nanyone that dares to ravage the forest.
Fruits are its favorite foods. This gourmet\ncarefully picks out just the ripe ones using\nits sonar.
It flies around in search of fruit to eat. It uses\nultrasonic waves to detect which fruits are ripe.
Although it has a violent disposition, if you give\nit a nice ripe fruit that it loves, Noivern will\nsuddenly become tame.
This hot-blooded Pokémon attacks anything it\nsees with ultrasonic waves that can\ncrush boulders.
This is Zygarde’s form when it has gathered\n50% of its cells. It wipes out all those who\noppose it, showing not a shred of mercy.
It’s thought to be monitoring the ecosystem.\nThere are rumors that even greater power lies\nhidden within it.
This is Zygarde’s form when about half of its\npieces have been assembled. It plays the role of\nmonitoring the ecosystem.
Some say it can change to an even more\npowerful form when battling those who threaten\nthe ecosystem.
This wary Pokémon uses photosynthesis to\nstore up energy during the day, while becoming\nactive at night.
Silently it glides, drawing near its targets. Before\nthey even notice it, it begins to pelt them with\nvicious kicks.
It sends its feathers, which are as sharp as\nblades, flying in attack. Its legs are strong,\nso its kicks are also formidable.
It feels relaxed in tight, dark places and has\nbeen known to use its Trainer’s pocket or bag\nas a nest.
A bit of a dandy, it spends its free time\npreening its wings. Its preoccupation with any\ndirt on its plumage can leave it unable to battle.
It throws sharp feathers called blade quills\nat enemies or prey. It seldom misses.
This narcissistic Pokémon is a clean freak.\nIf you don’t groom it diligently, it will stop\nlistening to you.
Supremely sensitive to the presence of others,\nit can detect opponents standing behind it,\nflinging its sharp feathers to take them out.
It fires arrow quills from its wings with such\nprecision, they can pierce a pebble at distances\nover a hundred yards.
Although basically cool and cautious, when it’s\ncaught by surprise, it’s seized by panic.
It nocks its arrow quills and shoots them at\nopponents. When it simply can’t afford to miss,\nit tugs the vine on its head to improve its focus.
Decidueye can nock and fire an arrow at an\nenemy in a tenth of a second, so its battles are\ndecided in the blink of an eye.
While grooming itself, it builds up fur inside its\nstomach. It sets the fur alight and spews fiery\nattacks, which change based on how it coughs.
It doesn’t allow its emotions to be easily seen.\nEarning its trust takes time. It prefers solitude.
If you try too hard to get close to it, it won’t\nopen up to you. Even if you do grow close, giving\nit too much affection is still a no-no.
Its coat regrows twice a year. When the time\ncomes, Litten sets its own body on fire and\nburns away the old fur.
At its throat, it bears a bell of fire. The bell rings\nbrightly whenever this Pokémon spits fire.
It boasts powerful front legs. With a single\npunch, it can bend an iron bar right over.
It can act spoiled if it grows close to its Trainer.\nA powerful Pokémon, its sharp claws can leave\nits Trainer’s whole body covered in scratches.
When its mane is standing on end, you can tell\nit’s feeling good. When it isn’t feeling well, its fur\nwill lie down flat.
This Pokémon has a violent, selfish disposition.\nIf it’s not in the mood to listen, it will ignore its\nTrainer’s orders with complete nonchalance.
After hurling ferocious punches and flinging\nfurious kicks, it finishes opponents off by\nspewing fire from around its navel.
Although it’s rough mannered and egotistical, it\nfinds beating down unworthy opponents boring.\nIt gets motivated for stronger opponents.
When its fighting spirit is set alight, the flames\naround its waist become especially intense.
This Pokémon snorts body fluids from its nose,\nblowing balloons to smash into its foes.\nIt’s famous for being a hard worker.
This Pokémon can control water bubbles. It\npractices diligently so it can learn to make\nbig bubbles.
The balloons it inflates with its nose grow\nlarger and larger as it practices day by day.
Popplio gets on top of its bouncy water balloons\nto jump higher. It’s quite the acrobatic fighter!
A skillful dancer, it creates a sequence of water\nballoons as it dances, and briskly bombards\nits enemies.
It cares deeply for its companions. When its\nTrainer is feeling down, it performs a cheery\ndance to try and help.
It gets excited when it sees a dance it doesn’t\nknow. This hard worker practices diligently until\nit can learn that dance.
It attacks by smacking its enemies with the\nexploding water balloons that it creates.
It controls its water balloons with song. The\nmelody is learned from others of its kind and is\npassed down from one generation to the next.
Its singing voice is its chief weapon in battle.\nThis Pokémon’s Trainer must prioritize the daily\nmaintenance of its throat at all costs.
To Primarina, every battle is a stage. It takes\ndown its prey with beautiful singing\nand dancing.
Also known as a songstress, it has a fantastical\nlook on moonlit nights when it leads its colony\nin song.
It can peck at a rate of 16 times a second to\ndrill holes in trees. It uses the holes for food\nstorage and for nesting.
This Pokémon feeds on berries, whose leftover\nseeds become the ammunition for the attacks it\nfires off from its mouth.
It pecks at trees with its hard beak. You can\nget some idea of its mood or condition from the\nrhythm of its pecking.
It may look spindly, but its neck muscles are\nheavy-duty. It can peck at a tree 16 times\nper second!
It eats berries and stores their seeds in its\nbeak. When it encounters enemies or prey,\nit fires off all the seeds in a burst.
By bending its beak, it can produce a variety of\ncalls and brand itself a noisy nuisance for\nits neighbors.
It can bend the tip of its beak to produce over\na hundred different cries at will.
From its mouth, it fires the seeds of berries\nit has eaten. The scattered seeds give rise\nto new plants.
When it battles, its beak heats up. The\ntemperature can easily exceed 212 degrees\nFahrenheit, causing severe burns when it hits.
Within its beak, its internal gas ignites,\nexplosively launching seeds with enough power\nto pulverize boulders.
They smack beaks with others of their kind to\ncommunicate. The strength and number of hits\ntell each other how they feel.
Known for forming harmonious couples, this\nPokémon is brought to wedding ceremonies as a\ngood luck charm.
With its sharp fangs, it will bite anything.\nIt did not originally live in Alola but was\nimported from another region.
It wanders around in a never-ending search for\nfood. At dusk, it collapses from exhaustion and\nfalls asleep on the spot.
Its stomach takes up most of its long torso.\nIt’s a big eater, so the amount Trainers have to\nspend on its food is no laughing matter.
Although it will eat anything, it prefers fresh\nliving things, so it marches down streets\nin search of prey.
When it finds a trace of its prey, it patiently\nstakes out the location...but it’s always snoozing\nby nightfall.
It adores having Rattata and Raticate for dinner,\nbut as it’s diurnal, it never encounters them.\nThis Pokémon boasts incredible patience.
Although it wasn’t originally found in Alola, this\nPokémon was brought over a long time ago\nwhen there was a huge Rattata outbreak.
Patient by nature, this Pokémon loses control of\nitself and pounces when it spots its favorite\nmeal—Rattata!
Its strong jaw enables it to scrape trees and\nslurp out the sap. It normally lives underground.
They often gather near places frequented by\nelectric Pokémon in order to avoid being\nattacked by bird Pokémon.
If you find its nest, you shouldn’t stick your\nhand inside. You’ll get bitten by an\nirritated Grubbin.
It spits a sticky thread to stop opponents in\ntheir tracks, and then it grabs them in its\nsharp, sturdy mandibles to take them down.
Its body is capable of storing electricity. On\ncamping trips, people are grateful to have\none around.
From the food it digests, it generates electricity,\nand it stores this energy in its electric sac.
It buries itself in fallen leaves and barely\nmoves, munching away on humus. If you\naccidentally step on one, you’ll get a shock!
Its stout shell provides excellent defense from\nattacks. It uses electricity on\npersistent opponents.
It zips around, on sharp lookout for an opening.\nIt concentrates electrical energy within its large\njaws and uses it to zap its enemies.
It produces electricity via an electrical organ in\nits abdomen. It overwhelms bird Pokémon with\nshocking beams of electrical energy.
It has an organ that generates electricity in its\nabdomen. It concentrates energy in its strong\njaws and fires off powerful jolts of electricity.
Vikavolt flusters opponents with acrobatic\nflying maneuvers. This creates an opening for\nit to deliver an electric beam attack.
While guarding its weak points with its pincers,\nit looks for an opening and unleashes punches.\nWhen it loses, it foams at the mouth and faints.
It punches so much, its pincers often come off\nfrom overuse, but they grow back quickly. What\nlittle meat they contain is rich and delicious.
Its hard pincers are well suited to both offense\nand defense. Fights between two Crabrawler\nare like boxing matches.
Crabrawler has been known to mistake\nExeggutor for a coconut tree and climb it. The\nenraged Exeggutor shakes it off and stomps it.
It aimed for the top but got lost and ended up\non a snowy mountain. Being forced to endure\nthe cold, this Pokémon evolved and grew fur.
It just throws punches indiscriminately. In times\nof desperation, it can lop off its own pincers\nand fire them like rockets.
It stores coldness in its pincers and pummels its\nfoes. It can even smash thick walls of ice\nto bits!
Before it stops to think, it just starts pummeling.\nThere are records of its turning back\navalanches with a flurry of punches.
It beats its wings together to create fire.\nAs it moves in the steps of its beautiful dance,\nit bathes opponents in intense flames.
This Oricorio has sipped red nectar. Its\npassionate dance moves cause its enemies\nto combust in both body and mind.
It wins the hearts of its enemies with its\npassionate dancing and then uses the opening\nit creates to burn them up with blazing flames.
This Oricorio has drunk red nectar. If its Trainer\ngives the wrong order, this passionate Pokémon\nbecomes fiercely angry.
It feeds on the nectar and pollen of flowers.\nBecause it’s able to sense auras, it can identify\nwhich flowers are about to bloom.
Myriads of Cutiefly flutter above the heads of\npeople who have auras resembling those\nof flowers.
Nectar and pollen are its favorite fare. In fields\nof flowers, it gets into skirmishes with\nButterfree over food.
Cutiefly can pick up the auras of living things. It\nskillfully reads those auras to predict its foes’\nmovements and make fools of them.
It rolls up pollen into puffs. It makes many\ndifferent varieties, some used as food and\nothers used in battle.
Some of Ribombee’s pollen puffs are highly\nnutritious. They are sometimes sold\nas supplements.
Rain makes pollen damp, so Ribombee hates\nrain. When it sees ominous clouds, it finds a\nhollow in a tree, where it waits stock-still.
It can predict the weather from moisture levels\nand wind direction. Ribombee only reveals itself\nwhen there are a few clear days in a row.
It’s considered to be a good Pokémon for\nbeginners because of its friendliness, but its\ndisposition grows rougher as it grows up.
This Pokémon has lived with people since times\nlong ago. It can sense when its Trainer is in the\ndumps and will stick close by its Trainer’s side.
As they develop, their disposition grows more\nviolent and aggressive. Many Trainers find them\ntoo much to handle and abandon them.
When it rubs the rocks on its neck against you,\nthat’s proof of its love for you. However, the\nrocks are sharp, so the gesture is quite painful!
Its quick movements confuse its enemies.\nWell equipped with claws and fangs, it also uses\nthe sharp rocks in its mane as weapons.
When properly raised from a young age, it will\nbecome a trustworthy partner that will\nabsolutely never betray its Trainer.
The sharp rocks in its mane can cut like knives.\nLycanroc wears its prey down by degrees\nbefore finishing them off.
The rocks in its mane are sharper than a knife.\nFragments that break off are treasured as\ngood luck charms.
When it’s in trouble, its eyes moisten and begin\nto shine. The shining light attracts its comrades,\nand they stand together against their enemies.
It’s awfully weak and notably tasty, so everyone\nis always out to get it. As it happens, anyone\ntrying to bully it receives a painful lesson.
They’re weak, so they move in schools.\nHowever, they can also often be seen all alone,\nhaving strayed from the school.
When it’s in a jam, its shining eyes attract\nothers of its kind. The light from its eyes is\nvisible almost 25 miles away.
It plunges the poison spike on its head into its\nprey. When the prey has weakened, Mareanie\ndeals the finishing blow with its 10 tentacles.
It’s found crawling on beaches and seafloors.\nThe coral that grows on Corsola’s head is as\ngood as a five-star banquet to this Pokémon.
They eat Corsola branches, so Mareanie are\nhated by craftsmen who work with Corsola\nbranches that have naturally fallen off.
Aside from its head, its body parts\nregenerate quickly if they’re cut off. After a\ngood night’s sleep, Mareanie is back to normal.
Toxapex crawls along the ocean floor on its\n12 legs. It leaves a trail of Corsola bits\nscattered in its wake.
Those attacked by Toxapex’s poison will suffer\nintense pain for three days and three nights.\nPost-recovery, there will be some aftereffects.
To attack, this Pokémon sends toxic spikes\nflying at its enemies. Ones that come close get\nmown down by the claws on its feet.
With its 12 legs, it creates a dome to shelter\nwithin. The flow of the tides doesn’t affect\nToxapex in there, so it’s very comfortable.
The mud stuck to Mudbray’s hooves enhances\nits grip and its powerful running gait.
It has a stubborn, individualistic disposition.\nEating dirt, making mud, and playing in the mire\nall form part of its daily routine.
It loves playing in the mud. If it isn’t showered\nwith mud on a daily basis, it gets stressed\nout and stops listening to its Trainer.
Possessing mighty power, Mudbray can be\nloaded with 50 times its own body weight\nand will be totally fine.
It spits a mud that provides resistance to both\nwind and rain, so the walls of old houses were\noften coated with it.
Its heavy, mud-covered kicks are its best\nmeans of attack, and it can reduce large trucks\nto scrap without breaking a sweat.
It remains calm and unmoving no matter the\nsituation. It mixes dirt with the saliva in its\nmouth to make a special kind of mud.
It can trudge mountain roads without rest\nfor three days and three nights, all the while\ndragging a 10-ton load.
It crawls onto the land in search of food.\nIts water bubble allows it to breathe and\nprotects its soft head.
When it comes across enemies or potential prey,\nthis Pokémon smashes its\nwater-bubble-covered head into them.
When two Dewpider meet, they display their\nwater bubbles to each other. Then the one with\nthe smaller bubble gets out of the other’s way.
It can only breathe oxygen that has dissolved in\nwater, so it wears a water bubble on its head\nwhen it walks around on land.
It delivers headbutts with the water bubble\non its head. Small Pokémon get sucked into\nthe bubble, where they drown.
Despite what its appearance suggests, it cares\nfor others. If it finds vulnerable, weak Pokémon,\nit protectively brings them into its water bubble.
It usually passes its time in the water. When its\nbelly is full, it stores its subdued prey in the\nwater bubble on its head.
It has a habit of storing things it values in its\nwater bubble. If its Trainer doesn’t watch out,\nAraquanid will try to put them in its bubble!
During the day, it sleeps and soaks up light.\nWhen night falls, it walks around looking\nfor a safer place to sleep.
They give off a sweet and refreshing scent.\nCutiefly often gather near the tall grass where\nFomantis are hiding.
When the sun rises, Fomantis spreads its four\nleaves and bathes in the sunlight. The tip of its\nhead has a pleasant aroma.
It loves the sunshine. When it basks in the\nsunlight regularly, it grows up with\nvivid coloration.
It requires a lot of effort to maintain Lurantis’s\nvivid coloring, but some collectors enjoy this\nwork and treat it as their hobby.
It fires beams from its sickle-shaped petals.\nThese beams are powerful enough to cleave\nthrough thick metal plates.
For self-protection, it pretends to be a bug\nPokémon. Both of its arms bear\nkeen-edged petals.
As it slashes into its enemies, it looks like it’s\ndancing. Its elegant appearance has led some\nto call it the most glamorous Grass Pokémon.
It scatters spores that flicker and glow. Anyone\nseeing these lights falls into a deep slumber.
As it drowses the day away, it nourishes itself\nby sucking from tree roots. It wakens at the fall\nof night, wandering off in search of a new tree.
It scatters its shining spores around itself.\nEven though they’re dangerous, nighttime tours\nof forests where Morelull live are popular.
It likes damp dark places. When night falls, the\nspores filling the caps of its mushrooms glow.
Forests where Shiinotic live are treacherous to\nenter at night. People confused by its strange\nlights can never find their way home again.
It emits flickering spores that cause drowsiness.\nWhen its prey succumb to sleep, this Pokémon\nfeeds on them by sucking in their energy.
It puts its prey to sleep and siphons off their\nvitality through the tip of its arms. If one of its\nkind is weakened, it helps by sending it vitality.
When it starts fighting for territory with\nParasect, the entire area gets completely\ncoated in spores!
It burns its bodily fluids to create a poisonous\ngas. When its enemies become disoriented from\ninhaling the gas, it attacks them.
Volcanoes or dry, craggy places are its home.\nIt emanates a sweet-smelling poisonous gas\nthat attracts bug Pokémon, then attacks them.
The males will do whatever the females tell\nthem. They give the females most of their food.\nDue to malnutrition, the males can’t evolve.
It weakens opponents and sends them\nreeling with its poisonous gas. Salandit doesn’t\ndeal well with Spinda, since it’s always reeling.
For some reason, only females have been found.\nIt creates a reverse harem of male Salandit that\nit lives with.
Filled with pheromones, its poisonous gas can\nbe diluted to use in the production of\nluscious perfumes.
Salazzle lives deep in caves and forces the\nSalandit it has attracted with its pheromones\nto serve it.
It punishes Salandit that couldn’t bring it food\nwith a fierce slap of its flame-spewing palm.
Despite its adorable appearance, when it gets\nangry and flails about, its arms and legs could\nknock a pro wrestler sprawling.
A touch from anyone except a known friend\nsends it into a surging frenzy. It’s an incredibly\ndangerous Pokémon.
It boasts power enough to split large trees in\nhalf. The organ on its rear releases an odor that\nit uses to communicate with others of its kind.
Stufful hates to be hugged or touched in any\nway. It will squirm, thrash, and resist with\namazing power.
This immensely dangerous Pokémon\npossesses overwhelming physical strength.\nIts habitat is generally off-limits.
This Pokémon has the habit of hugging its\ncompanions. Many Trainers have left this world\nafter their spines were squashed by its hug.
It waves its hands wildly in intimidation and\nwarning. Life is over for anyone who doesn’t\nrun away as fast as possible.
It boasts tremendous physical strength. Many\npeople call it the most dangerous Pokémon in\nthe Alola region.
A delectable aroma pours from its body.\nThey are often swallowed whole by Toucannon\nlured by that wafting deliciousness.
Although it’s too sugary for human consumption,\nBounsweet’s sweat can be watered down into a\njuice with just the right amount of sweetness.
Because of its sweet, delicious aroma, bird\nPokémon are always after it, but it’s not\nintelligent enough to care.
It tries to resist being swallowed by a bird\nPokémon by spinning the sepals on its head.\nIt’s usually a fruitless attempt.
The sepals on its head developed to protect its\nbody. These are quite hard, so even if pecked\nby bird Pokémon, this Pokémon is totally fine.
This Pokémon is always bouncing around\nenergetically. Other Pokémon are attracted by\nits lively appearance and pleasant aroma.
It’s protected by its hard sepals, so it plays\nwith bird Pokémon without worry. They peck it\nrelentlessly, but it doesn’t care.
It bounces around, swinging the sepals on its\nhead with abandon. They’re quite painful when\nthey smack you!
Its long, striking legs aren’t just for show but to\nbe used to kick with skill. In victory, it shows off\nby kicking the defeated, laughing boisterously.
A Pokémon known for the beauty of its\nwell-shaped legs, it sometimes appears as a\nmascot in advertisements for beauty salons.
A master of grand and beautiful kicks, it can\nknock out even kickboxing champions with a\nsingle blow.
A Pokémon with an aggressive personality and\na mastery of kicking, it cackles every time it\nkicks an opponent.
It attaches flowers to its highly nutritious vine.\nThis revitalizes the flowers, and they give off\nan aromatic scent.
Baths prepared with the flowers from its vine\nhave a relaxing effect, so this Pokémon\nis a hit with many people.
It stretches sticky vines out from its head and\npicks flowers to adorn itself with. When it\ndoesn’t have any flowers, it feels uneasy.
It picks flowers and sticks them to its body\nwith fluids it produces. The aroma that wafts\nfrom its petals has a healing effect.
Known for its extreme intelligence, this Pokémon\nwill look down on inexperienced Trainers, so it’s\nbest suited to veteran Trainers.
Deep in the jungle, high in the lofty canopy, this\nPokémon abides. On rare occasions, it shows up\nat the beach to match wits with Slowking.
It normally spends its time meditating in the\ntreetops. It throws Poké Balls and gives other\nPokémon orders as it pleases.
Oranguru don’t get along with each other, so\nthey’re always engaging in battles of wits to\ndecide which one is superior.
They form groups of roughly 20 individuals.\nTheir mutual bond is remarkable—they will never\nlet down a comrade.
They battle with hard berries for weapons.\nTheir techniques are passed from the boss to\nthe group, generation upon generation.
They use their saliva to stick leaves to their\nshoulders. You can tell what troop they belong\nto from the position of the leaves.
Berries are its weapons as well as the staple of\nits diet. The one that can throw a berry the\nfarthest is the boss of the troop.
This Pokémon is a coward. As it desperately\ndashes off, the flailing of its many legs leaves a\nsparkling clean path in its wake.
Its habitat varies from beaches to seabeds.\nA natural scavenger, it will gleefully chow down\non anything edible, no matter how rotten.
It will pick up anything it finds on the ground.\nSometimes it finds coins, so Murkrow and\nMeowth will go after it.
An astonishingly cowardly Pokémon, Wimpod\nwill whir its legs at high speeds to run away if\nanything comes near it.
With a flashing slash of its giant sharp claws,\nit cleaves seawater—or even air—right in two.
It battles skillfully with its six arms, but spends\nmost of its time peacefully meditating in caves\ndeep beneath the sea.
The shell covering its body is as hard as\ndiamond. This Pokémon will do anything it\ntakes to win.
Its claws, which it can extend and retract at\nwill, are its greatest weapons. Golisopod is\nsometimes accompanied by Wimpod.
Born from a sand mound playfully built by a\nchild, this Pokémon embodies the grudges of\nthe departed.
It takes control of anyone who puts a hand in its\nmouth. And so it adds to the accumulation of\nits sand-mound body.
It likes the shovel on its head, so Sandygast\nwill get serious and fight any children who come\nto take it back.
If you build sand mounds when you’re playing,\ndestroy them before you go home, or they\nmay get possessed and become Sandygast.
Possessed people controlled by this Pokémon\ntransformed its sand mound into a castle. As it\nevolved, its power to curse grew ever stronger.
Buried beneath the castle are masses of\ndried-up bones from those whose vitality\nit has drained.
Each of its grains of sand has its own will.\nPalossand eats small Pokémon and siphons\naway their vital essence while they’re still alive.
Once it has whipped up a sandstorm to halt\nits opponents in their tracks, this terrifying\nPokémon snatches away their vitality.
It lives in shallow seas, such as areas near a\nbeach. It can eject its internal organs, which it\nuses to engulf its prey or battle enemies.
These Pokémon line the beaches. The sticky\nmucous that covers their bodies can be used to\nsoothe sunburned skin. How convenient!
The tradition known as Pyukumuku chucking\nstarted from the custom of throwing Pyukumuku\nback into the sea after they wash onshore.
Its entire body is covered in its own slime. If you\naccidentally step on one, you’ll slip, and it will\nget mad and smack you!
The heavy control mask it wears suppresses its\nintrinsic capabilities. This Pokémon has some\nhidden special power.
Due to the danger that this synthetic Pokémon\nmay go on a rampage, it wears a control mask\nto restrain its power.
A Pokémon weapon developed for a specific\nmission, it went berserk during an experiment,\nso it was cryogenically frozen.
There’s danger of its going on a rampage, so its\ntrue power is sealed away beneath its\ncontrol mask.
Its trust in its partner is what awakens it.\nThis Pokémon is capable of changing its type,\na flexibility that is well displayed in battle.
Although its name was Type: Null at first, the\nboy who evolved it into this form gave it the\nname by which it is now known.
This is its form once it has awakened and\nevolved. Freed from its heavy mask, its speed is\ngreatly increased.
Through the bond it formed with its Trainer, its\nwill was strengthened, and it was able to\ndestroy its control mask.
Originally making its home in the ozone layer,\nit hurtles to the ground when the shell enclosing\nits body grows too heavy.
Strong impacts can knock it out of its shell. This\nPokémon was born from mutated nanoparticles.
It lives in the ozone layer, where it becomes\nfood for stronger Pokémon. When it tries to run\naway, it falls to the ground.
Although its outer shell is uncommonly durable,\nthe shock of falling to the ground smashes the\nshell to smithereens.
It is born asleep, and it dies asleep. All its\nmovements are apparently no more than the\nresults of it tossing and turning in its dreams.
The log it holds was given to it by its parents at\nbirth. It has also been known to cling to the arm\nof a friendly Trainer.
It stays asleep from the moment it’s born.\nWhen it falls into a deep sleep, it stops\nmoving altogether.
It remains asleep from birth to death as a result\nof the sedative properties of the leaves that\nform its diet.
The shell on its back is chemically unstable\nand explodes violently if struck. The hole in its\nstomach is its weak point.
It gushes fire and poisonous gases from its\nnostrils. Its dung is an explosive substance and\ncan be put to various uses.
It lives in volcanoes and eats sulfur and other\nminerals. Materials from the food it eats form\nthe basis of its explosive shell.
Its exploding shell poses a real danger but\nis sensitive to moisture. On rainy days,\nTurtonator takes silent refuge in caves.
The spiny fur on its back is normally at rest.\nWhen this Pokémon becomes agitated, its fur\nstands on end and stabs into its attackers.
The long hairs on its back act as lightning rods.\nThe bolts of lightning it attracts are stored as\nenergy in its electric sac.
When it’s surprised or agitated, the 14 fur\nspikes on its back will stand up involuntarily.
Its capacity to produce electricity is somewhat\nlimited, so it gets charged up by letting lightning\nstrike it!
Its actual appearance is unknown. A scholar\nwho saw what was under its rag was\noverwhelmed by terror and died from the shock.
A lonely Pokémon, it conceals its terrifying\nappearance beneath an old rag so it can get\ncloser to people and other Pokémon.
Although it’s a quiet, lonely Pokémon, if you try\nto look at what’s under its rag, it will become\nagitated and resist violently.
A gust of wind revealed what hides under this\nPokémon’s rag to a passing Trainer, who went\nhome and died painfully that very night.
When it unleashes its psychic power from the\nprotuberance on its head, the grating sound\nof grinding teeth echoes through the area.
It stuns its prey with psychokinesis and then\ngrinds them to mush with its strong teeth.\nEven Shellder’s shell is no match for it.
It burrows beneath the sand, radiating\npsychic power from the protuberance on its\nhead. It waits for prey as it surveys the area.
Its skin is thick enough to fend off Mareanie’s\nspikes. With its robust teeth, Bruxish crunches\nup the spikes and eats them.
It has a compassionate personality, but if it is\nangered, it completely destroys its surroundings\nwith its intense breath.
This Pokémon is friendly to people and loves\nchildren most of all. It comes from deep in the\nmountains to play with children it likes in town.
If a child it has made friends with is bullied,\nDrampa will find the bully’s house and burn it to\nthe ground.
It appears in towns and plays with the children.\nDrampa will protect kids when they’re in danger,\nso their moms don’t have to worry.
Swinging its massive anchor, it can KO Wailord\nin a single blow. What appears to be green\nseaweed is actually its body.
The soul of seaweed adrift in the waves became\nreborn as this Pokémon. It maintains itself with\nnew infusions of seabed detritus and seaweed.
It wraps its prey in green seaweed and sucks\naway their vitality. It only likes to go after big\nprey like Wailord.
Its chain-like green seaweed can stretch\noutward for hundreds of yards. For some\nreason, it gets along well with Skrelp.
It expresses its feelings by smacking\nits scales. Metallic sounds echo through\nthe tall mountains where Jangmo-o lives.
They live in mountains where no trace of\nhumans can be detected. Jangmo-o grow\nlittle by little as they battle one another.
It smacks the scales on its head against rocks\nor against the ground to frighten its opponents.\nIt can also contact its friends with these noises.
It will never show an enemy its back in battle.\nAncient warriors liked Jangmo-o for its valiant\ndisposition and made it one of their own.
It leaps at its prey with a courageous shout.\nIts scaly punches tear its opponents to shreds.
It sheds and regrows its scales on a continuous\nbasis. The scales become harder and sharper\neach time they’re regrown.
It makes noise by clanging its scales together.\nWhen the rhythm has reached its peak,\nHakamo-o attacks.
The scales it sheds can be molded and\nprocessed to make pots and pans. They\nconduct heat well, so they’re a popular item.
When it spots enemies, it threatens them by\njingling the scales on its tail. Weak opponents\nwill crack and flee in panic.
Its rigid scales function as offense and defense.\nIn the past, its scales were processed and used\nto make weapons and other commodities.
When it howls after finishing off its prey, the\nmetallic sounds of its celebrating comrades can\nbe heard from all around.
It battles valiantly with its fists, which are\narmored in steel scales. Kommo-o specializes\nin uppercuts.
This guardian deity of Melemele is brimming with\ncuriosity. It summons thunderclouds and stores\ntheir lightning inside its body.
It confuses its enemies by flying too quickly for\nthe eye to follow. It has a hair-trigger temper\nbut forgets what made it angry an instant later.
Although it’s called a guardian deity, if a person\nor Pokémon puts it in a bad mood, it will become\na malevolent deity and attack.
The lightning-wielding guardian deity of\nMelemele, Tapu Koko is brimming with curiosity\nand appears before people from time to time.
This guardian deity of Akala is guilelessly cruel.\nThe fragrant aroma of flowers is the source of\nits energy.
As it flutters about, it scatters its strangely\nglowing scales. Touching them is said to restore\ngood health on the spot.
It heals the wounds of people and Pokémon by\nsprinkling them with its sparkling scales. This\nguardian deity is worshiped on Akala.
Although called a guardian deity, Tapu Lele is\ndevoid of guilt about its cruel disposition and\ncan be described as nature incarnate.
It pulls large trees up by the roots and swings\nthem around. It causes vegetation to grow,\nand then it absorbs energy from the growth.
The guardian deity of Ula’ula is a lazy Pokémon.\nIt commands plants to immobilize its foes and\nthen deals them a savage blow with its horns.
Although it’s called a guardian deity, it’s violent\nenough to crush anyone it sees as an enemy.
It makes ringing sounds with its tail to let others\nknow where it is, avoiding unneeded conflicts.\nThis guardian deity of Ula’ula controls plants.
The dense fog it creates brings the downfall\nand destruction of its confused enemies.\nOcean currents are the source of its energy.
The guardian deity of Poni, it can control water.\nPeople say it can create pure water that will\nwash away any uncleanness.
This guardian deity of Poni Island manipulates\nwater. Because it lives deep within a thick fog,\nit came to be both feared and revered.
Although it’s called a guardian deity, terrible\ncalamities sometimes befall those who\nrecklessly approach Tapu Fini.
Its body is gaseous and frail. It slowly grows as\nit collects dust from the atmosphere.
In ages past, it was called the child of the stars.\nIt’s said to be a Pokémon from another world,\nbut no specific details are known.
Even though its helpless, gaseous body can be\nblown away by the slightest breeze, it doesn’t\nseem to care.
Whether or not it’s a Pokémon from this world\nis a mystery. When it’s in a jam, it warps away\nto a safe place to hide.
Motionless as if dead, its body is faintly warm to\nthe touch. In the distant past, it was called the\ncocoon of the stars.
There’s something accumulating around the\nblack core within its hard shell. People think\nthis Pokémon may come from another world.
The king who ruled Alola in times of antiquity\ncalled it the “cocoon of the stars” and built\nan altar to worship it.
As it absorbs light, Cosmoem continues to grow.\nIts golden shell is surprisingly solid.
It is said to live in another world. The intense\nlight it radiates from the surface of its body can\nmake the darkest of nights light up like midday.
This Pokémon is said to be a male evolution of\nCosmog. At the activation of its third eye, it\ndeparts for another world.
Sometimes the result of its opening an Ultra\nWormhole is that energy and life-forms from\nother worlds are called here to this world.
In writings from the distant past, it’s called by\nthe name “the beast that devours the sun.”
It is said to be a female evolution of Cosmog.\nWhen its third eye activates, away it flies to\nanother world.
Said to live in another world, this Pokémon\ndevours light, drawing the moonless dark veil of\nnight over the brightness of day.
Records of it exist in writings from long, long\nago, where it was known by the name\n“the beast that calls the moon.”
It sometimes summons unknown powers and\nlife-forms here to this world from holes that\nlead to other worlds.
One of several mysterious Ultra Beasts. People\non the street report observing those infested\nby it suddenly becoming violent.
One of the Ultra Beasts. It’s unclear whether or\nnot this Pokémon is sentient, but sometimes it\ncan be observed behaving like a young girl.
A life-form from another world, it was dubbed\na UB and is thought to produce a\nstrong neurotoxin.
It appeared in this world from an Ultra\nWormhole. Nihilego appears to be a parasite\nthat lives by feeding on people and Pokémon.
This Ultra Beast appeared from another world.\nIt shows off its body, but whether that display\nis a boast or a threat remains unclear.
A mysterious life-form called an Ultra Beast.\nWitnesses saw it pulverize a dump truck with a\nsingle punch.
Although it’s alien to this world and a danger\nhere, it’s apparently a common organism in the\nworld where it normally lives.
Buzzwole goes around showing off its\nabnormally swollen muscles. It is one kind\nof Ultra Beast.
One of the dangerous Ultra Beasts, it has been\nspotted running across the land at\nterrific speeds.
One of the Ultra Beasts. It refuses to touch\nanything, perhaps because it senses some\nuncleanness in this world.
A life-form that lives in another world, its body\nis thin and supple, but it also possesses\ngreat power.
Although it’s alien to this world and a danger\nhere, it’s apparently a common organism in the\nworld where it normally lives.
One of the mysterious life-forms known as Ultra\nBeasts. Astonishing electric shocks emanate\nfrom its entire body, according to witnesses.
It appeared from the Ultra Wormhole. It raided a\npower plant, so people think it energizes itself\nwith electricity.
Although it’s alien to this world and a danger\nhere, it’s apparently a common organism in the\nworld where it normally lives.
They’ve been dubbed Ultra Beasts. Some of\nthem stand unmoving, like trees, with their\narms and legs stuck into the ground.
It appeared from the Ultra Wormhole. Witnesses\nobserved it flying across the sky at high speed.
One kind of Ultra Beast. Witnesses have seen it\nburn down a forest by expelling gas from its\ntwo arms.
One of the dangerous UBs, high energy readings\ncan be detected coming from both of its\nhuge arms.
Although it’s alien to this world and a danger\nhere, it’s apparently a common organism in the\nworld where it normally lives.
This Ultra Beast came from the Ultra Wormhole.\nIt seems not to attack enemies on its own, but\nits sharp body is a dangerous weapon in itself.
One of the Ultra Beast life-forms, it was\nobserved cutting down a gigantic steel tower\nwith one stroke of its blade.
This Ultra Beast’s body, which is as thin as\npaper, is like a sharpened sword.
Although it’s alien to this world and a danger\nhere, it’s apparently a common organism in the\nworld where it normally lives.
It has gobbled mountains and swallowed whole\nbuildings, according to reports. It’s one of the\nUltra Beasts.
A dangerous Ultra Beast, it appears to be eating\nconstantly, but for some reason its droppings\nhave never been found.
Although it’s alien to this world and a danger\nhere, it’s apparently a common organism in the\nworld where it normally lives.
An unknown life-form called a UB. It may be\nconstantly hungry—it is certainly always\ndevouring something.
Reminiscent of the Ultra Beasts, this life-form,\napparently asleep underground, is thought to\nhave come from another world in ancient times.
Light is apparently the source of its energy.\nIt has an extraordinarily vicious disposition\nand is constantly firing off laser beams.
It looks somehow pained as it rages around in\nsearch of light, which serves as its energy.\nIt’s apparently from another world.
Light is the source of its energy. If it isn’t\ndevouring light, impurities build up in it and on it,\nand Necrozma darkens and stops moving.
This artificial Pokémon, constructed more than\n500 years ago, can understand human speech\nbut cannot itself speak.
Its mechanized body is merely a vessel. Its true\nself is its Soul-Heart, an artificial soul.
It synchronizes its consciousness with others\nto understand their feelings. This faculty makes\nit useful for taking care of people.
Built roughly 500 years ago by a scientist,\nthe part called the Soul-Heart is the\nactual life-form.
Able to conceal itself in shadows, it never\nappears before humans, so its very existence\nwas the stuff of myth.
It lurks in the shadows of others, copying their\nmovements and powers. This Pokémon is craven\nand cowering.
It slips into the shadows of others and mimics\ntheir powers and movements. As it improves, it\nbecomes stronger than those it’s imitating.
It sinks into the shadows of people and\nPokémon, where it can understand their feelings\nand copy their capabilities.
This Ultra Beast is well enough liked to be\nchosen as a first partner in its own world.
An Ultra Beast that lives in a different world, it\ncackles wildly as it sprays its opponents with\npoison from the needles on its head.
It stores hundreds of liters of poisonous liquid\ninside its body. It is one of the organisms known\nas UBs.
One kind of Ultra Beast, it fires a glowing,\nvenomous liquid from its needles. This liquid\nis also immensely adhesive.
It appeared from an Ultra Wormhole. Each one\nappears to be made up of many life-forms\nstacked one on top of each other.
When stone walls started moving and attacking,\nthe brute’s true identity was this mysterious\nlife-form, which brings to mind an Ultra Beast.
It slithers toward people. Then, without warning,\nit triggers the explosion of its own head.\nIt’s apparently one kind of Ultra Beast.
A UB that appeared from an Ultra Wormhole, it\ncauses explosions, then takes advantage of\nopponents’ surprise to rob them of their vitality.
It electrifies its claws and tears its opponents\napart with them. Even if they dodge its attack,\nthey’ll be electrocuted by the flying sparks.
It approaches its enemies at the speed of\nlightning, then tears them limb from limb with\nits sharp claws.
This is the form Castform takes on the\nbrightest of days. Its skin is unexpectedly hot\nto the touch, so approach with care.
This is Castform’s form when basking in fair\nweather. Its body is warm and toasty.
This is the form Castform takes on bright days.\nIn an experiment where Castform was placed in\nfront of a heater, it didn’t change to this form.
Castform changes to this form when it basks in\nbright sunlight. When you touch its glowing skin,\nit feels all dried out!
This is the form Castform takes when soaked\nwith rain. When its body is compressed, water\nwill seep out as if from a sponge.
This is Castform’s form during a downpour of\nrain. Its body retains moisture and gets slippery.
Castform changes to this form when rain hits it.\nIts body is soft and slightly swollen with water.
This is Castform’s form when pelted by rain. In\nan experiment where it was placed in a shower,\nthis Pokémon didn’t change to this form.
This is the form Castform takes when covered\nin snow. Its body becomes an ice-like material,\nwith a temperature near 23 degrees Fahrenheit.
This is Castform’s form when caught in a\nhailstorm. Its cold skin is as smooth as ice.
This is the form Castform takes when hit by\nhail. In an experiment where it was placed in a\nfreezer, it didn’t change to this form.
This is Castform’s form when caught in a\nhailstorm. Its whole body is chilled, and its skin\nis partially frozen!
Even Basculin, which devours everything it can\nwith its huge jaws, is nothing more than food to\norganisms stronger than itself.
Some people call it “the thug of the lake.”\nWhether the differences in color are meaningful\nis not yet known.
As a result of Mega Evolution, its power has\nbeen entirely converted into psychic energy,\nand it has lost all strength in its muscles.
Its hidden psychic power has been unleashed.\nA glance at someone gives it knowledge of the\ncourse of that person’s life, from birth to death.
It sends out psychic power from the red organ\non its forehead to foresee its opponents’\nevery move.
Having traded away its muscles, Alakazam’s\ntrue power has been unleashed. With its\npsychic powers, it can foresee all things.
Gengar’s relationships are warped. It has no\ninterest in opponents unless it perceives them\nas prey.
The energy of Mega Evolution awakened it.\nIt sinks into another dimension, where it keeps\na patient watch for its chance to attack.
It tries to take the lives of anyone and everyone.\nIt will even try to curse the Trainer who is\nits master!
Mega Evolution has made it possible for Gengar\nto access other dimensions. Its entire body is\nbrimming with strange power.
Mega Kangaskhan’s strength derives from the\nmother’s happiness about her child’s growth.\nWatching it grow up keeps her spirits high.
Thanks to Mega Evolution, its child grows. But\nas the child is good only at fighting and nothing\nelse, its mother feels uneasy about its future.
The explosive energy the child is bathed in\ncauses temporary growth. The mother is beside\nherself with worry about it.
When the mother sees the back of her Mega-\nEvolved child, it makes her think of the day\nwhen her child will inevitably leave her.
The influence of Mega Evolution leaves it in a\nstate of constant excitement. It pierces enemies\nwith its two large horns before shredding them.
Bathed in the energy of Mega Evolution, its\nwings become unusually developed. It flies\nat speeds of approximately 30 mph.
After Mega Evolution, it becomes able to fly.\nPerhaps because it’s so happy, it rarely\ntouches the ground.
It zips around at blistering speeds, looking for\nan opening to skewer its opponent on its\ngiant pincers.
Mega Evolution also affects its brain, leaving\nno other function except its destructive instinct\nto burn everything to cinders.
It jets water from the orifices on its sides,\nstreaking above the water surface at\nsupersonic speed.
Mega Evolution places a burden on its body.\nThe stress causes it to become all the\nmore ferocious.
It zooms out of the water at Mach speeds. Even\nlarge ships caught in its path are split cleanly\nin two!
Part of its body has become stone. Some\nscholars claim that this is Aerodactyl’s\ntrue appearance.
When it Mega Evolves, it becomes more vicious\nthan ever before. Some say that’s because its\nexcess of power is causing it pain.
It will attack anything that moves.\nMega Evolution is a burden on its body, so it’s\nincredibly irritated.
Mega Evolution awakened some dormant genes,\nbringing back the sharp rocks that once\ncovered Aerodactyl’s entire body.
Excess energy from Mega Evolution stimulates\nits genes, and the wool it had lost grows\nin again.
Massive amounts of energy intensely stimulated\nAmpharos’s cells, apparently awakening its\nlong-sleeping dragon’s blood.
The excess energy that bathes this Pokémon\nkeeps it in constant danger of overflow. It can’t\nsustain a battle over long periods of time.
Due to the effects of Mega Evolution, its pincers\nhave taken on a more diabolical form, ripping\nanything they pinch to shreds.
It stores the excess energy from Mega Evolution,\nso after a long time passes, its body starts\nto melt.
It’s better at beating things than grasping them.\nWhen it battles for a long time, the weight of its\npincers becomes too much to bear.
It can grip things with its two horns and lift\n500 times its own body weight.
A tremendous influx of energy builds it up, but\nwhen Mega Evolution ends, Heracross is\nbothered by terrible soreness in its muscles.
